abstract.p: Charles Flynn letter on April 4 article says Yuma, Ariz, is developing entirely new approach to water shortages that emphasizes cooperation not confrontation

block.p: ''No Longer Waiting for Rain, an Arid West Takes Action'' (front page, April 4), about how the West is dealing with long-term water shortages, was an important contribution to the issue. We here in Yuma, Ariz., are also developing an entirely new approach that emphasizes cooperation, not confrontation.

''No Longer Waiting for Rain, an Arid West Takes Action'' (front page, April 4), about how the West is dealing with long-term water shortages, was an important contribution to the issue. We here in Yuma, Ariz., are also developing an entirely new approach that emphasizes cooperation, not confrontation.

The Quechan Indian tribe and the City of Yuma, along with private landowners, are leading an effort to restore the Yuma East Wetlands -- 1,418 acres along the Colorado River that are overgrown with nonnative vegetation.

One might ask: what does environmental restoration have to do with the issue of water shortages? Clearing nonnative vegetation and planting drought-tolerant trees (cottonwoods, willows, mesquite) have the potential of saving lots of water. It is estimated that we will save 890 acres feet of water when we complete the East Wetlands project.
There are win-win solutions to our problems, and we need to avoid wasting energy on litigation and fighting over the dwindling conventional supplies.
The writer is executive director, Yuma Crossing National Heritage Area.
